docs.lead_paragraph: Why is health care in America so expensive, and will the Democrats' legislation sufficiently control those costs? We put those questions to a conservative policy analyst and a liberal one. Their answers were very different, but the ultimate conclusions were similar: the legislation will not do enough to slow the nation's out-of-control spending on health care.

headline.kicker: PRESCRIPTIONS MAKING SENSE OF THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE

docs.abstract: Conservative and liberal policy analysts-Joseph Anthos of American Enterprise Institute and Prof Jacob Hacker of Yale University-offer their takes on why health care in America is so expensive and whether Democrats' legislation will sufficiently control costs (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Five big health insurance companies funneled millions of dollars to the United States Chamber of Commerce for television commercials attacking Congressional efforts to overhaul the health care system, the National Journal reported Tuesday.

headline.main: Insurers Helped Pay for TV Attack Ads

docs.abstract: Health insurers helped finance TV ads attacking the Congressional health care effort, the National Journal reported.
docs.snippet: Health insurers helped finance TV ads attacking the Congressional health care effort, the National Journal reported.

docs.lead_paragraph: People like to live too much.

headline.main: Why Does Health Care Cost So Much?

docs.abstract: Why is health care in America so expensive? And will the legislation developing in Washington do enough to control costs?
docs.snippet: Why is health care in America so expensive? And will the legislation developing in Washington do enough to control costs?

docs.lead_paragraph: The federal government released its latest estimates of health spending last week, and they allow for some telling comparisons. In 2008, the country spent $2.3 trillion on medical care, or 16.2 percent of gross domestic product and $7,681 per person.
docs.abstract: It exists right here in the United States.
docs.snippet: It exists right here in the United States.

docs.lead_paragraph: Fewer Americans now approve of the way that President Barack Obama is handling the economy and health care, pushing his overall job rating below the crucial 50 percent mark, according to the latest CBS News poll.

headline.main: Poll: Obama's Ratings on Health Care, Economy Drop Lower

docs.abstract: A new CBS polls shows fewer Americans approving of the way the president is handling two top issues.
docs.snippet: A new CBS polls shows fewer Americans approving of the way the president is handling two top issues.

docs.lead_paragraph: As President Obama signaled his willingness to compromise at least a bit on a proposal that would levy a substantial excise tax on the most expensive health plans, called Cadillac plans, Hollywood is still waiting to exhale.

headline.main: Hollywood, With Its Expensive Health Plans, Worries About Reform

docs.abstract: Hollywood, where expensive health plans are the norm, expresses outrage and bewilderment about the proposed tax.
docs.snippet: Hollywood, where expensive health plans are the norm, expresses outrage and bewilderment about the proposed tax.

docs.lead_paragraph: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

docs.lead_paragraph: Monologue | Monday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: Listen to this. In his weekly radio and Internet address, President Obama said "we are on the verge" of guaranteeing Americans health insurance "whether they lose their job, change jobs, move or get sick," which means Jay, Conan and I are going to be just fine. So don't worry.

docs.lead_paragraph: It seems that President Obama's drive to recover billions in bailout funds might have more than just fiscal benefits, at least from the White House's point of view.

headline.main: The Early Word: Money, Money, Money

docs.abstract: The White House is looking for ways to recoup some of the money used to bail out the financial system.
